event.descr:
An SG has been newly added to Director.

sgHostname %parm[#1]%;

sgSerialNumber %parm[#2]%;

sgDeviceId %parm[#3]%;

sgDeviceName %parm[#4]%;
event.logmsg: blueCoatDirectorSgChgSgAdded trap received sgHostname=%parm[#1]% sgSerialNumber=%parm[#2]% sgDeviceId=%parm[#3]% sgDeviceName=%parm[#4]%

event.descr:

sgHostname %parm[#1]%;

sgDeviceId %parm[#3]%;

sgDeviceName %parm[#4]%;
event.logmsg: blueCoatDirectorSgChgSgDeleted trap received sgHostname=%parm[#1]% sgSerialNumber=%parm[#2]% sgDeviceId=%parm[#3]% sgDeviceName=%parm[#4]%

event.descr:
An SG has transitioned to the CONNECTED state. SG's that do not implement the Health Monitoring CLI commands will typically enter this state and remain here as long as Director can maintain an SSH connection to that SG.

sgHostname %parm[#1]%;

sgSerialNumber %parm[#2]%;

sgDeviceId %parm[#3]%;

sgDeviceName %parm[#4]%;
event.logmsg: blueCoatDirectorSgChgSgConnected trap received sgHostname=%parm[#1]% sgSerialNumber=%parm[#2]% sgDeviceId=%parm[#3]% sgDeviceName=%parm[#4]%

event.descr:
An SG has transitioned to the DISCONNECTED state.

sgHostname %parm[#1]%;

sgSerialNumber %parm[#2]%;

sgDeviceId %parm[#3]%;

sgDeviceName %parm[#4]%;
event.logmsg: blueCoatDirectorSgChgSgDisconnected trap received sgHostname=%parm[#1]% sgSerialNumber=%parm[#2]% sgDeviceId=%parm[#3]% sgDeviceName=%parm[#4]%

event.descr:
An SG has transitioned to the OK state.

sgHostname %parm[#1]%;

sgSerialNumber %parm[#2]%;

sgDeviceId %parm[#3]%;

sgDeviceName %parm[#4]%;
event.logmsg: blueCoatDirectorSgChgSgOk trap received sgHostname=%parm[#1]% sgSerialNumber=%parm[#2]% sgDeviceId=%parm[#3]% sgDeviceName=%parm[#4]%

event.descr:
An SG has transitioned to the WARNING state. Note that even if the SG encounters additional trouble, (also of 'warning' severity), a second trap will NOT be sent. If, however, an SG that currently is in warning state encounters trouble of severity 'critical', a _Critical trap WILL be sent.

sgHostname %parm[#1]%;

sgSerialNumber %parm[#2]%;

sgDeviceId %parm[#3]%;

sgDeviceName %parm[#4]%;
event.logmsg: blueCoatDirectorSgChgSgWarning trap received sgHostname=%parm[#1]% sgSerialNumber=%parm[#2]% sgDeviceId=%parm[#3]% sgDeviceName=%parm[#4]%

event.descr:
An SG has transitioned to the CRITICAL state. Note that even if the SG encounters additional trouble, (also of 'critical' severity), a second trap will NOT be sent. Likewise, if the SG encounters additional trouble of severity 'warning' a _Warning trap will NOT be sent, as the SG is still in state critical.

sgHostname %parm[#1]%;

sgSerialNumber %parm[#2]%;

sgDeviceId %parm[#3]%;

sgDeviceName %parm[#4]%;
event.logmsg: blueCoatDirectorSgChgSgCritical trap received sgHostname=%parm[#1]% sgSerialNumber=%parm[#2]% sgDeviceId=%parm[#3]% sgDeviceName=%parm[#4]%

event.descr:
An SG has been added via the auto-registration process.

sgHostname %parm[#1]%;

sgSerialNumber %parm[#2]%;

sgDeviceId %parm[#3]%;

sgDeviceName %parm[#4]%;
event.logmsg: blueCoatDirectorSgChgSgAutoregistered trap received sgHostname=%parm[#1]% sgSerialNumber=%parm[#2]% sgDeviceId=%parm[#3]% sgDeviceName=%parm[#4]%

event.descr:
An SG's attempt to register via auto-registration process failed .

sgHostname %parm[#1]%;

sgSerialNumber %parm[#2]%;

sgDeviceId %parm[#3]%;

sgDeviceName %parm[#4]%;
event.logmsg: blueCoatDirectorSgChgSgAutoregistrationFailed trap received sgHostname=%parm[#1]% sgSerialNumber=%parm[#2]% sgDeviceId=%parm[#3]% sgDeviceName=%parm[#4]%

event.descr:
If reported by the Primary Director, that Primary Director could not reach the Secondary in order to log-in and check its Standby status, (called 'heartbeat'). If reported by the Secondary Director, that Secondary has not 'heard' the Primary log-in for a long time. Either way, the network link between the two Directors is not working properly. Any changes made on the Primary will not by synced to the Secondary, (assuming the Primary is the Active Director). Remediation: fix the network between the two Directors. In the mean-time, be careful that no Operator makes the Secondary Director Active, or you might reach a condition where you have two Active Directors with changes on each.

standbyPartnerIpaddr %parm[#1]%;

After a _PartnerReachabilityLost condition was reported, this Director could once again reach (or be reached by) its Partner Director.

standbyPartnerIpaddr %parm[#1]%;

The reporting Director has been forced to be the Primary Director in a Standby pair by Operator command.

standbyPartnerIpaddr %parm[#1]%;

The reporting Director has been forced to be the Secondary Director in a Standby pair by Operator command.

standbyPartnerIpaddr %parm[#1]%;

The reporting Director has been forced to run StandAlone (outside a Standby pair), by Operator command.

standbyPartnerIpaddr %parm[#1]%;

The reporting Director has been forced to the Active state by Operator command.

standbyPartnerIpaddr %parm[#1]%;

Description.

standbyPartnerIpaddr %parm[#1]%;

After a _SyncFailed condition was reported, a successive sync operation succeeded and sync was reestablished. (This notification is NOT reported after every successful sync completes).

standbyPartnerIpaddr %parm[#1]%;

While running in the Active state, the Primary Director found the Secondary in the Active state. In such a case, the Primary automatically 'backs-off' to the Inactive state. Remediation: There are two common ways of getting into this condition: 1. With the Primary Director in the Active state and the Secondary Director in the Reserve state, the network between the two goes down. An Operator promotes the Secondary to the Active state. On the first 'heartbeat' after the network comes back up, this double-Active condition is detected. 2. With the Primary Director in the Active state and the Secondary Director in the Reserve state, the Primary Director powers-off. An Operator promotes the Secondary to the Active state. When the Primary powers-up, this double-Active condition is detected. In both cases, an Operator will have to determine which Director(s) have changes (if any), and decide which set of changes to keep when they make the Primary Active again.

standbyPartnerIpaddr %parm[#1]%;

There are two possibilities: the Director setup to be this Director's partner can be configured to be part of a pair, or not. If that partner Director is configured to be part of a pair: This [Primary] Director logged-into the Secondary, (as part of the 'heartbeat' process), and asked that Secondary Director who it thought it's Primary was. Unfortunately, that Secondary 'pointed-to' a THIRD Director, when it was expected that it would point back to this Director. The IPaddr of that THIRD Director is reported by the 'standbyPartnersPrimary' varbind in this notification. If that partner Director is StandAlone: The Primary will find no Primary configured on that other Director, and will report '0.0.0.0' for the varbind 'standbyPartnersPrimary' in this notification. Remediation: an Operator must check and resolve the configuration on either/both Directors in the pair.

standbyPartnerIpaddr %parm[#1]%;

standbyPartnersPrimary %parm[#2]%;

After reporting a _PartnerConfigInvalid condition, this Director once again found its Secondary to correctly 'point-back' to this Director as partner.

standbyPartnerIpaddr %parm[#1]%;

The Secondary Director has transitioned to the Reserve state in response to seeing the Primary transition to the Active state. This transition is not automatic since it is only the second-order effect of operator intervention on the Primary Director. Receipt of this notification confirms that the Secondary has 'heard' the Primary step-up to Active and as a result the Secondary transitions to the Reserve state. If the Secondary does not report this notification immediately after the Primary is promoted via Make-Active, the network between the two Directors may be down, (which would shortly be reported by a _PartnerReachabilityLost notification). In such a case, operators must be especially cautious, as they would then be running with both Directors in the Active state, and may inadvertently make changes on both Directors, thus creating a problem when the standby pair is rejoined (one set of changes or the other will be lost).

standbyPartnerIpaddr %parm[#1]%;

At the start of an attack a notification is generated with 'deviceAttackStatus = underAttack(2)'. At the end of an attack a notification is generated with 'deviceAttackStatus = noAttack(1)'.

deviceAttackName %parm[#1]%;

deviceAttackStatus %parm[#2]%;

noAttack(1) underAttack(2)

The disk status warrants a notification.

deviceDiskStatus %parm[#1]%;

present(1) initializing(2) inserted(3) offline(4) removed(5) notpresent(6) empty(7) bad(8) unknown(9)

A notification is generated when the health of a monitored system changes.

deviceHealthCheckMessage %parm[#1]%;

A notification is generated when the health of the SG system changes.

bluecoatSgHealthMonitorMessage %parm[#1]%;

A notification is generated when triggered by policy

devicePolicyMessage %parm[#1]%;

The sensor value warrants a notification.

deviceSensorName %parm[#1]%;

deviceSensorValue %parm[#2]%;

deviceSensorCode %parm[#3]%;

ok(1) unknown(2) notInstalled(3) voltageLowWarning(4) voltageLowCritical(5) noPower(6) voltageHighWarning(7) voltageHighCritical(8) voltageHighSevere(9) temperatureHighWarning(10) temperatureHighCritical(11) temperatureHighSevere(12) fanSlowWarning(13) fanSlowCritical(14) fanStopped(15)
event.logmsg: deviceSensorTrap trap received deviceSensorName=%parm[#1]% deviceSensorValue=%parm[#2]% deviceSensorCode=%parm[#3]%

event.descr:
A notification is sent when the deviceUsagePercent exceeds a threshold. This is no longer functional. Use health monitoring instead.

deviceUsageName %parm[#1]%;

deviceUsagePercent %parm[#2]%;

deviceUsageStatus %parm[#3]%;

ok(1) high(2)
event.logmsg: deviceUsageTrap trap received deviceUsageName=%parm[#1]% deviceUsagePercent=%parm[#2]% deviceUsageStatus=%parm[#3]%

event.descr:
Successful av engine/pattern update.

avVendorName %parm[#1]%;

avEngineVersion %parm[#2]%;

avPatternVersion %parm[#3]%;

avPatternDateTime %parm[#4]%;
event.logmsg: avAntivirusUpdateSuccess trap received avVendorName=%parm[#1]% avEngineVersion=%parm[#2]% avPatternVersion=%parm[#3]% avPatternDateTime=%parm[#4]%

event.descr:
Av engine/pattern update failed, avUpdateFailureReason provides more details.

avUpdateFailureReason %parm[#1]%;

avVendorName %parm[#2]%;

avEngineVersion %parm[#3]%;

avPatternVersion %parm[#4]%;

avPatternDateTime %parm[#5]%;
event.logmsg: avAntivirusUpdateFailed trap received avUpdateFailureReason=%parm[#1]% avVendorName=%parm[#2]% avEngineVersion=%parm[#3]% avPatternVersion=%parm[#4]% avPatternDateTime=%parm[#5]%

event.descr:
Infected file detected at avUrl.

avUrl %parm[#1]%;

avVirusDetails %parm[#3]%;

event.descr:
File served without scanning. It could not be scanned completely due to a scan exception.

avErrorCode %parm[#2]%;

avErrorDetails %parm[#3]%;

event.descr:
